extracted_data.requirement: A Data Fiduciary shall establish a grievance redressal mechanism.
extracted_data.requirement_description: Data Fiduciaries must have a process in place to handle and resolve complaints from Data Principals.

controls.control: The Data Fiduciary shall establish a grievance redressal policy that outlines the procedures for handling and resolving complaints from data subjects. The policy shall be approved by the management and communicated to all employees.

The Data Fiduciary shall designate a Grievance Redressal Officer (GRO) who shall be responsible for handling and resolving complaints from data subjects. The GRO shall be trained on the grievance redressal policy and procedures.

The Data Fiduciary shall establish a grievance redressal mechanism that allows data subjects to submit complaints in a timely and efficient manner. The mechanism shall include a complaint form, email address, and physical address for submitting complaints.

The Data Fiduciary shall acknowledge receipt of complaints from data subjects within [timeframe, e.g., 3 working days] and respond to complaints within [timeframe, e.g., 15 working days]. The response shall include a resolution or an explanation of the actions being taken to resolve the complaint.

The Data Fiduciary shall maintain a record of all complaints received, including the date of receipt, nature of the complaint, and the outcome of the complaint. The record shall be kept for a minimum of [timeframe, e.g., 5 years].

controls.control_title: Review and Update the Grievance Redressal Policy
controls.control: The Data Fiduciary shall review and update the grievance redressal policy and procedures annually or as needed. The review shall include feedback from data subjects and employees to ensure that the policy and procedures are effective and efficient.

extracted_data.requirement: A Data Fiduciary shall obtain consent from the parent or guardian before processing personal data of a child or person with disability.
extracted_data.requirement_description: Data Fiduciaries must obtain consent from the parent or guardian before processing personal data of a child or person with disability.

controls.control_title: Obtain Explicit Consent from Parents or Guardians
controls.control: The Data Fiduciary must obtain explicit consent from the parent or guardian of a child or person with disability before processing their personal data. This consent must be obtained in writing, preferably through a signed agreement or contract, and must clearly outline the purpose and scope of data processing.

The Data Fiduciary must verify the authenticity of the consent obtained from the parent or guardian. This can be done by checking the signature on the consent form, verifying the identity of the parent or guardian, or using other reliable methods to confirm the consent is genuine.

The Data Fiduciary must maintain a record of the consent obtained from the parent or guardian, as well as details of the personal data processed. This documentation must be kept for a minimum of 5 years and must be made available to relevant authorities upon request.

The Data Fiduciary must ensure that all staff members involved in processing personal data of children or persons with disabilities are trained on the requirements for obtaining consent from parents or guardians. This training must cover the importance of explicit consent, the methods for obtaining consent, and the consequences of non-compliance.

The Data Fiduciary must regularly review and update its consent processes to ensure they remain effective and compliant with relevant regulations. This includes reviewing consent forms, verifying the authenticity of consent, and ensuring that staff are trained on any changes to the consent process.

controls.control: The Significant Data Fiduciary shall appoint a Data Protection Officer (DPO) who is responsible for overseeing the organization's data protection practices and ensuring compliance with relevant data protection regulations. The DPO shall be a senior-level employee with expertise in data protection and shall report directly to the highest level of management.

The Significant Data Fiduciary shall define the DPO's responsibilities, including but not limited to, data protection impact assessments, data breach notification, and data subject rights. The DPO's responsibilities shall be documented in a written policy and communicated to all employees.

The Significant Data Fiduciary shall provide the DPO with training on data protection regulations, data protection impact assessments, and data breach notification. The training shall be provided within 6 months of the DPO's appointment and shall be repeated annually.

The Significant Data Fiduciary shall ensure that the DPO operates independently and is not influenced by business or commercial considerations. The DPO shall have unfettered access to all data and systems, and shall be able to report directly to the highest level of management without fear of retribution.

The Significant Data Fiduciary shall document the DPO's appointment, including the DPO's name, contact information, and responsibilities. The documentation shall be maintained in a secure and accessible location and shall be updated annually.

controls.control_title: Establish a Data Protection Impact Assessment (DPIA) Policy

controls.control_title: Identify Data Processing Activities Requiring DPIA
controls.control: Conduct a thorough risk assessment to identify data processing activities that involve personal data and have a high risk of violating data protection regulations. This includes activities such as data collection, storage, transmission, and processing.
Appoint a dedicated DPIA coordinator who will be responsible for overseeing the DPIA process, ensuring compliance with the policy, and coordinating with relevant stakeholders.

Create a standardized DPIA template that includes all necessary information and questions to be answered during the DPIA process. The template should be reviewed and updated regularly to ensure it remains relevant and effective.

Offer regular training sessions for personnel involved in the DPIA process to ensure they understand their roles and responsibilities, as well as the procedures and requirements outlined in the policy.

Maintain accurate and up-to-date records of all DPIAs conducted, including the results, recommendations, and actions taken to mitigate any identified risks. These records should be retained for a minimum of 5 years and made available for inspection by regulatory authorities.

controls.control: Establish a clear and transparent process for handling DSARs, including a designated contact point for data subjects to submit requests. This process should include procedures for verifying the identity of the data subject, responding to requests within a reasonable timeframe, and providing access to personal data in a format that is easily accessible.

Maintain an up-to-date inventory of personal data processed by the organization, including the categories of data, the sources of the data, and the purposes for which the data is used. This inventory should be used to identify and map personal data flows within the organization.

Develop a standardized DSAR form that is easily accessible to data subjects, which includes clear instructions on how to submit a request and what information is required to verify the identity of the data subject.

Send an acknowledgement to the data subject within a reasonable timeframe (e.g. 3-5 business days) of receiving a DSAR, confirming receipt of the request and providing an estimated timeframe for responding to the request.

Respond to DSARs within a reasonable timeframe (e.g. 30 calendar days), providing access to personal data in a format that is easily accessible, and including information on the purposes for which the data is used, the categories of data processed, and the recipients of the data.

extracted_data.article_text:

to a request made in writing by such other Data Fiduciary for the purpose of prevention or
detection or investigation of offences or cyber incidents, or for prosecution or punishment
of offences.
12. (1) A Data Principal shall have the right to correction, completion, updating and
erasure of her personal data for the processing of which she has previously given consent,
including consent as referred to in clause (a) of section 7, in accordance with any requirement
or procedure under any law for the time being in force.
(2) A Data Fiduciary shall, upon receiving a request for correction, completion or
updating from a Data Principal,—
(a) correct the inaccurate or misleading personal data;
(b) complete the incomplete personal data; and
(c) update the personal data.
(3) A Data Principal shall make a request in such manner as may be prescribed to the
Data Fiduciary for erasure of her personal data, and upon receipt of such a request, the Data
Fiduciary shall erase her personal data unless retention of the same is necessary for the
specified purpose or for compliance with any law for the time being in force.
13. (1) A Data Principal shall have the right to have readily available means of grievance
redressal provided by a Data Fiduciary or Consent Manager in respect of any act or omission
of such Data Fiduciary or Consent Manager regarding the performance of its obligations in
relation to the personal data of such Data Principal or the exercise of her rights under the
provisions of this Act and the rules made thereunder.
(2) The Data Fiduciary or Consent Manager shall respond to any grievances referred
to in sub-section (1) within such period as may be prescribed from the date of its receipt for
all or any class of Data Fiduciaries.
(3) The Data Principal shall exhaust the opportunity of redressing her grievance
under this section before approaching the Board.
14. (1) A Data Principal shall have the right to nominate, in such manner as may be
prescribed, any other individual, who shall, in the event of death or incapacity of the Data
Principal, exercise the rights of the Data Principal in accordance with the provisions of this
Act and the rules made thereunder.
(2) For the purposes of this section, the expression “incapacity” means inability to
exercise the rights of the Data Principal under the provisions of this Act or the rules made
thereunder due to unsoundness of mind or infirmity of  body.
15.  A Data Principal shall perform the following duties, namely:—
(a) comply with the provisions of all applicable laws for the time being in force
while exercising rights under the provisions of this Act;
(b) to ensure not to impersonate another person while providing her personal
data for a specified purpose;
(c) to ensure not to suppress any material information while providing her
personal data for any document, unique identifier, proof of identity or proof of address
issued by the State or any of its instrumentalities;
(d) to ensure not to register a false or frivolous grievance or complaint with a
Data Fiduciary or the Board; and
(e) to furnish only such information as is verifiably authentic, while exercising
the right to correction or erasure under the provisions of this Act or the rules made
thereunder.

Communicate the outcome of the erasure request to the Data Principal, including whether the request was successful or not, and provide any necessary explanations or justifications. This will help maintain transparency and trust with Data Principals.

controls.control: The organization shall conduct regular compliance audits to ensure adherence to applicable laws and regulations. These audits shall be conducted at least annually and shall cover all aspects of the organization's operations.
The organization shall establish a compliance program that includes policies, procedures, and training to ensure that all employees understand and comply with applicable laws and regulations.

The organization shall provide regular compliance training to employees to ensure that they understand their roles and responsibilities in complying with applicable laws and regulations.

The organization shall designate a compliance officer who is responsible for ensuring that the organization complies with applicable laws and regulations. The compliance officer shall report directly to the CEO or other senior executive.
The organization shall maintain accurate and complete records of its compliance activities, including audit reports, training records, and other relevant documents.

controls.control: Implement a robust authentication and authorization system to ensure that only authorized users can access the system. This includes multi-factor authentication, role-based access control, and least privilege access.

Implement a comprehensive logging and monitoring system to track all user activity, including login attempts, data access, and system modifications. This will help detect and prevent impersonation attempts.
Implement IP blocking and geolocation features to prevent users from accessing the system from unauthorized locations. This will help prevent impersonation attempts from outside the organization.

Educate users on the risks of impersonation and the importance of using strong passwords and multi-factor authentication. This will help prevent users from falling victim to phishing attacks and other impersonation attempts.

Implement session management controls to ensure that user sessions are properly managed, including session timeouts, idle timeouts, and secure cookie management. This will help prevent session hijacking and impersonation attempts.

Conduct regular security audits to identify vulnerabilities and weaknesses in the system that could be exploited by an attacker to impersonate a user. This will help identify and remediate potential security risks.

extracted_data.article_text:
SEC. 1] THE GAZETTE OF INDIA EXTRAORDINARY 11
CHAPTER IV
SPECIAL PROVISIONS
16. (1) The Central Government may, by notification, restrict the transfer of personal
data by a Data Fiduciary for processing to such country or territory outside India as may be
so notified.
(2) Nothing contained in this section shall restrict the applicability of any law for the
time being in force in India that provides for a higher degree of protection for or restriction
on transfer of personal data by a Data Fiduciary outside India in relation to any personal
data or Data Fiduciary or class thereof.
17. (1) The provisions of Chapter II, except sub-sections (1) and (5) of section 8, and
those of Chapter III and section 16 shall not apply where—
(a) the processing of personal data is necessary for enforcing any legal right or
claim;
(b) the processing of personal data by any court or tribunal or any other body
in India which is entrusted by law with the performance of any judicial or quasi-judicial
or regulatory or supervisory function, where such processing is necessary for the
performance of such function;
(c) personal data is processed in the interest of prevention, detection,
investigation or prosecution of any offence or contravention of any law for the time
being in force in India;
(d) personal data of Data Principals not within the territory of India is processed
pursuant to any contract entered into with any person outside the territory of India
by any person based in India;
(e) the processing is necessary for a scheme of compromise or arrangement or
merger or amalgamation of two or more companies or a reconstruction by way of
demerger or otherwise of a company, or transfer of undertaking of one or more company
to another company, or involving division of one or more companies, approved by a
court or tribunal or other authority competent to do so by any law for the time being
in force; and
(f) the processing is for the purpose of ascertaining the financial information
and assets and liabilities of any person who has defaulted in payment due on account
of a loan or advance taken from a financial institution, subject to such processing
being in accordance with the provisions regarding disclosure of information or data
in any other law for the time being in force.
Explanation.— For the purposes of this clause, the expressions “default” and
“financial institution” shall have the meanings respectively assigned to them in
sub-sections (12) and (14) of section 3 of the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code, 2016.
Illustration.
X, an individual, takes a loan from Y , a bank.  X defaults in paying her monthly loan
repayment instalment on the date on which it falls due. Y may process the personal data of
X for ascertaining her financial information and assets and liabilities.
(2) The provisions of this Act shall not apply in respect of the processing of personal
data—
(a) by such instrumentality of the State as the Central Government may notify,
in the interests of sovereignty and integrity of India, security of the State, friendly
relations with foreign States, maintenance of public order or preventing incitement to
any cognizable offence relating to any of these, and the processing by the Central
Government of any personal data that such instrumentality may furnish to it; and

controls.control_title: Conduct a Risk Assessment for International Data Transfers
controls.control: The Data Fiduciary shall conduct a thorough risk assessment to identify potential risks associated with transferring personal data to countries or territories outside India. This assessment shall consider factors such as the recipient country's data protection laws, data breach history, and the level of data protection afforded to individuals.

controls.control_title: Obtain Prior Approval for International Data Transfers
controls.control: The Data Fiduciary shall obtain prior approval from the Central Government or the designated authority before transferring personal data to countries or territories outside India. This approval shall be obtained in accordance with the procedures and guidelines specified by the Central Government.

The Data Fiduciary shall implement data transfer agreements with the recipient country or territory that meet the requirements specified by the Central Government. These agreements shall include provisions for data protection, data security, and dispute resolution.

controls.control_title: Monitor and Review International Data Transfers
controls.control: The Data Fiduciary shall regularly monitor and review international data transfers to ensure compliance with the Central Government's requirements and the data transfer agreements. This review shall include an assessment of the data protection and security measures in place.

controls.control_title: Maintain Records of International Data Transfers
controls.control: The Data Fiduciary shall maintain accurate and up-to-date records of international data transfers, including the recipient country or territory, the type of data transferred, and the purpose of the transfer. These records shall be made available to the Central Government or the designated authority upon request.

controls.control_title: Conduct a Risk Assessment for International Data Transfers
controls.control: Conduct a thorough risk assessment to identify potential risks associated with transferring personal data outside India. This assessment should consider the laws and regulations of the countries where the data will be transferred, as well as the potential impact on the Data Fiduciary's business operations.

controls.control_title: Implement Standard Contractual Clauses (SCCs) or Binding Corporate Rules (BCRs)
controls.control: Implement SCCs or BCRs to ensure that personal data transferred outside India is protected in accordance with the laws and regulations of the countries where the data will be transferred. SCCs and BCRs provide a standardized framework for ensuring the protection of personal data in international data transfers.

controls.control_title: Maintain Records of International Data Transfers
controls.control: Maintain accurate and up-to-date records of all international data transfers, including the purpose of the transfer, the categories of data transferred, and the countries where the data will be transferred. These records should be kept for a minimum of 5 years and made available to regulatory authorities upon request.

controls.control_title: Provide Transparency to Data Subjects about International Data Transfers
controls.control: Provide clear and concise information to data subjects about the international data transfers that will be made, including the countries where the data will be transferred and the purposes of the transfer. This information should be made available through the Data Fiduciary's privacy policy or other publicly available documents.

controls.control_title: Monitor and Review International Data Transfers for Compliance
controls.control: Regularly monitor and review international data transfers to ensure compliance with applicable laws and regulations. This includes reviewing the SCCs or BCRs implemented, maintaining accurate records of international data transfers, and ensuring that data subjects are provided with clear information about the transfers.

controls.control_title: Exclusion of Provisions in Chapter II (except sub-sections 1 and 5 of section 8)
controls.control: Implement a system to identify and exclude provisions of Chapter II (except sub-sections 1 and 5 of section 8) from the compliance scope. This includes regular reviews of the organization's activities and processes to ensure that they are not subject to these provisions.

controls.control_title: Exclusion of Provisions in Chapter III
controls.control: Implement a system to identify and exclude provisions of Chapter III from the compliance scope. This includes regular reviews of the organization's activities and processes to ensure that they are not subject to these provisions.

Implement a system to identify and exclude provisions of section 16 from the compliance scope. This includes regular reviews of the organization's activities and processes to ensure that they are not subject to these provisions.
Maintain accurate and up-to-date documentation of the provisions excluded from the compliance scope, including the reasons for exclusion and the processes in place to ensure ongoing compliance.

Provide regular training and awareness programs for employees on the exclusions from the compliance scope, including the provisions of Chapter II (except sub-sections 1 and 5 of section 8), Chapter III, and section 16.

controls.control: Establish clear criteria for notifying the Central Government about the processing of personal data by an instrumentality of the State. This should include specific reasons, such as sovereignty and integrity of India, security of the State, friendly relations with foreign States, maintenance of public order, or preventing incitement to any cognizable offence. The criteria should be documented and communicated to all relevant stakeholders.

Develop a process for obtaining prior approval from the Central Government before exempting any instrumentality of the State from the provisions of this Act. This should include submitting a formal request with justification and waiting for approval before processing personal data without compliance with the Act.

Maintain accurate and up-to-date records of all exemptions granted by the Central Government. This should include the date of exemption, the reason for exemption, and the scope of the exemption. These records should be easily accessible to all relevant stakeholders.

Regularly review and update exemptions to ensure they remain valid and compliant with the Act. This should include monitoring changes in the law, regulations, or circumstances that may affect the exemption. Exemptions should be updated or revoked as necessary to maintain compliance.

Designate a senior official or committee to be responsible for ensuring compliance with the Act and the exemptions granted by the Central Government. This should include monitoring compliance, investigating any non-compliance, and taking corrective action as necessary.

controls.control: Personal data shall be anonymized before being used for research, archiving, or statistical purposes to prevent identification of Data Principals.
Only the minimum amount of personal data necessary for research, archiving, or statistical purposes shall be collected and processed.
Access to personal data for research, archiving, or statistical purposes shall be restricted to authorized personnel and shall be subject to approval and monitoring.
Personal data used for research, archiving, or statistical purposes shall be retained for the minimum period necessary and shall be deleted or anonymized after the retention period has expired.
Documentation of personal data usage for research, archiving, or statistical purposes shall be maintained to ensure transparency and accountability.
A Data Protection Impact Assessment (DPIA) shall be conducted before collecting and processing personal data for research, archiving, or statistical purposes to identify and mitigate potential risks.

CHAPTER V
D
ATA PROTECTION BOARD OF INDIA
18. (1) With effect from such date as the Central Government may, by notification,
appoint, there shall be established, for the purposes of this Act, a Board to be called the
Data Protection Board of India.
(2) The Board shall be a body corporate by the name aforesaid, having perpetual
succession and a common seal, with power, subject to the provisions of this Act, to acquire,
hold and dispose of property, both movable and immovable, and to contract and shall, by
the said name, sue or be sued.
(3) The headquarters of the Board shall be at such place as the Central Government
may notify.
19. (1) The Board shall consist of a Chairperson and such number of other Members
as the Central Government may notify.
(2) The Chairperson and other Members shall be appointed by the Central Government
in such manner as may be prescribed.
(3) The Chairperson and other Members shall be a person of ability, integrity and
standing who possesses special knowledge or practical experience in the fields of data
governance, administration or implementation of laws related to social or consumer
protection, dispute resolution, information and communication technology, digital economy,
law, regulation or techno-regulation, or in any other field which in the opinion of the Central
Government may be useful to the Board, and at least one among them shall be an expert in
the field of law.
20. ( 1) The salary, allowances and other terms and conditions of service of the
Chairperson and other Members shall be such as may be prescribed, and shall not be varied
to their disadvantage after their appointment.
(2) The Chairperson and other Members shall hold office for a term of two years and
shall be eligible for re-appointment.

extracted_data.article_text:
SEC. 1] THE GAZETTE OF INDIA EXTRAORDINARY 13
21. (1) A person shall be disqualified for being appointed and continued as the
Chairperson or a Member, if she—
(a) has been adjudged as an insolvent;
(b) has been convicted of an offence, which in the opinion of the Central
Government, involves moral turpitude;
(c) has become physically or mentally incapable of acting as a Member;
(d) has acquired such financial or other interest, as is likely to affect prejudicially
her functions as a Member; or
(e) has so abused her position as to render her continuance in office prejudicial
to the public interest.
(2) The Chairperson or Member shall not be removed from her office by the Central
Government unless she has been given an opportunity of being heard in the matter.
22. (1) The Chairperson or any other Member may give notice in writing to the Central
Government of resigning from her office, and such resignation shall be effective from the
date on which the Central Government permits her to relinquish office, or upon expiry of a
period of three months from the date of receipt of such notice, or upon a duly appointed
successor entering upon her office, or upon the expiry of the term of her office, whichever
is earliest.
(2) A vacancy caused by the resignation or removal or death of the Chairperson or
any other Member, or otherwise, shall be filled by fresh appointment in accordance with the
provisions of this Act.
(3) The Chairperson and any other Member shall not, for a period of one year from the
date on which they cease to hold such office, except with the previous approval of the
Central Government, accept any employment, and shall also disclose to the Central
Government any subsequent acceptance of employment with any Data Fiduciary against
whom proceedings were initiated by or before such Chairperson or other Member.
23. ( 1) The Board shall observe such procedure in regard to the holding of and
transaction of business at its meetings, including by digital means, and authenticate its
orders, directions and instruments in such manner as may be prescribed.
(2) No act or proceeding of the Board shall be invalid merely by reason of—
(a) any vacancy in or any defect in the constitution of the Board;
(b) any defect in the appointment of a person acting as the Chairperson or other
Member of the Board; or
(c) any irregularity in the procedure of the Board, which does not affect the
merits of the case.
(3) When the Chairperson is unable to discharge her functions owing to absence,
illness or any other cause, the senior-most Member shall discharge the functions of the
Chairperson until the date on which the Chairperson resumes her duties.
24. The Board may, with previous approval of the Central Government, appoint such
officers and employees as it may deem necessary for the efficient discharge of its functions
under the provisions of this Act, on such terms and conditions of appointment and service
as may be prescribed.
25. The Chairperson, Members, officers and employees of the Board shall be deemed,
when acting or purporting to act in pursuance of provisions of this Act, to be public
servants within the meaning of section 21 of the Indian Penal Code.

Establish a process for Chairperson and Members to disclose any potential conflicts of interest, including financial or other interests that may affect their functions as a Member, and to recuse themselves from decisions where a conflict of interest exists.

Implement a system to monitor and report any instances of position abuse by Chairperson and Members, and to take disciplinary action where necessary to prevent continuance in office prejudicial to the public interest.

Provide regular training and education for Chairperson and Members on their roles, responsibilities, and the requirements for their positions, including the need to disclose conflicts of interest and to avoid position abuse.

extracted_data.requirement_title: Removal of Chairperson or Member
extracted_data.article_text:
SEC. 1] THE GAZETTE OF INDIA EXTRAORDINARY 13
21. (1) A person shall be disqualified for being appointed and continued as the
Chairperson or a Member, if she—
(a) has been adjudged as an insolvent;
(b) has been convicted of an offence, which in the opinion of the Central
Government, involves moral turpitude;
(c) has become physically or mentally incapable of acting as a Member;
(d) has acquired such financial or other interest, as is likely to affect prejudicially
her functions as a Member; or
(e) has so abused her position as to render her continuance in office prejudicial
to the public interest.
(2) The Chairperson or Member shall not be removed from her office by the Central
Government unless she has been given an opportunity of being heard in the matter.
22. (1) The Chairperson or any other Member may give notice in writing to the Central
Government of resigning from her office, and such resignation shall be effective from the
date on which the Central Government permits her to relinquish office, or upon expiry of a
period of three months from the date of receipt of such notice, or upon a duly appointed
successor entering upon her office, or upon the expiry of the term of her office, whichever
is earliest.
(2) A vacancy caused by the resignation or removal or death of the Chairperson or
any other Member, or otherwise, shall be filled by fresh appointment in accordance with the
provisions of this Act.
(3) The Chairperson and any other Member shall not, for a period of one year from the
date on which they cease to hold such office, except with the previous approval of the
Central Government, accept any employment, and shall also disclose to the Central
Government any subsequent acceptance of employment with any Data Fiduciary against
whom proceedings were initiated by or before such Chairperson or other Member.
23. ( 1) The Board shall observe such procedure in regard to the holding of and
transaction of business at its meetings, including by digital means, and authenticate its
orders, directions and instruments in such manner as may be prescribed.
(2) No act or proceeding of the Board shall be invalid merely by reason of—
(a) any vacancy in or any defect in the constitution of the Board;
(b) any defect in the appointment of a person acting as the Chairperson or other
Member of the Board; or
(c) any irregularity in the procedure of the Board, which does not affect the
merits of the case.
(3) When the Chairperson is unable to discharge her functions owing to absence,
illness or any other cause, the senior-most Member shall discharge the functions of the
Chairperson until the date on which the Chairperson resumes her duties.
24. The Board may, with previous approval of the Central Government, appoint such
officers and employees as it may deem necessary for the efficient discharge of its functions
under the provisions of this Act, on such terms and conditions of appointment and service
as may be prescribed.
25. The Chairperson, Members, officers and employees of the Board shall be deemed,
when acting or purporting to act in pursuance of provisions of this Act, to be public
servants within the meaning of section 21 of the Indian Penal Code.

Maintain a record of all decisions to remove the Chairperson or Member from office, including the reasons for the decision and any supporting evidence. This will help to ensure transparency and accountability in the decision-making process.

Establish an independent review mechanism to review decisions to remove the Chairperson or Member from office. This can be achieved through an external review panel or an independent ombudsman, which can provide an impartial assessment of the decision-making process.

extracted_data.requirement_title: Chairperson's Powers and Responsibilities
extracted_data.article_text:
14 THE GAZETTE OF INDIA EXTRAORDINARY [P ART II—
26. The Chairperson shall exercise the following powers, namely:—
(a) general superintendence and giving direction in respect of all administrative
matters of the Board;
(b) authorise any officer of the Board to scrutinise any intimation, complaint,
reference or correspondence addressed to the Board; and
(c) authorise performance of any of the functions of the Board and conduct any
of its proceedings, by an individual Member or groups of Members and to allocate
proceedings among them.
CHAPTER VI
P
OWERS, FUNCTIONS AND PROCEDURE TO BE FOLLOWED BY BOARD
27. (1) The Board shall exercise and perform the following powers and functions,
namely:—
(a) on receipt of an intimation of personal data breach under sub-section (6) of
section 8, to direct any urgent remedial or mitigation measures in the event of a
personal data breach, and to inquire into such personal data breach and impose
penalty as provided in this Act;
(b) on a complaint made by a Data Principal in respect of a personal data breach
or a breach in observance by a Data Fiduciary of its obligations in relation to her
personal data or the exercise of her rights under the provisions of this Act, or on a
reference made to it by the Central Government or a State Government, or in compliance
of the directions of any court, to inquire into such breach and impose penalty as
provided in this Act;
(c) on a complaint made by a Data Principal in respect of a breach in observance
by a Consent Manager of its obligations in relation to her personal data, to inquire
into such breach and impose penalty as provided in this Act;
(d) on receipt of an intimation of breach of any condition of registration of a
Consent Manager, to inquire into such breach and impose penalty as provided in this
Act; and
(e) on a reference made by the Central Government in respect of the breach in
observance of the provisions of sub-section  (2) of section 37 by an intermediary, to
inquire into such breach and impose penalty as provided in this Act.
(2) The Board may, for the effective discharge of its functions under the provisions of
this Act, after giving the person concerned an opportunity of being heard and after recording
reasons in writing, issue such directions as it may consider necessary to such person, who
shall be bound to comply with the same.
(3) The Board may, on a representation made to it by a person affected by a direction
issued under sub-section ( 1) or sub-section ( 2), or on a reference made by the Central
Government, modify, suspend, withdraw or cancel such direction and, while doing so,
impose such conditions as it may deem fit, subject to which the modification, suspension,
withdrawal or cancellation shall have effect.
28. (1) The Board shall function as an independent body and shall, as far as practicable,
function as a digital office, with the receipt of complaints and the allocation, hearing and
pronouncement of decisions in respect of the same being digital by design, and adopt such
techno-legal measures as may be prescribed.
(2) The Board may, on receipt of an intimation or complaint or reference or directions
as referred to in sub-section (1) of section 27, take action in accordance with the provisions
of this Act and the rules made thereunder.

controls.control_title: Establish a Personal Data Breach Response Plan
controls.control: The organization shall develop and maintain a personal data breach response plan that outlines the procedures to be followed in the event of a breach. The organization shall designate a Data Protection Officer (DPO) who shall be responsible for overseeing the organization's personal data breach response plan and ensuring that all stakeholders are aware of their roles and responsibilities in the event of a breach.

The organization shall establish a process for notifying affected individuals and regulatory authorities in the event of a personal data breach. The process shall include a clear description of the information to be provided, the timing of the notification, and the procedures for handling inquiries and complaints.

The organization shall conduct regular risk assessments to identify potential personal data breaches and assess the likelihood and potential impact of such breaches. The results of these assessments shall be used to inform the development and implementation of the personal data breach response plan.

The organization shall maintain a log of all personal data breaches, including the date and time of the breach, the type of data involved, and the actions taken to contain and mitigate the breach. The log shall be used to track trends and identify areas for improvement in the organization's personal data breach response plan.

26. The Chairperson shall exercise the following powers, namely:—
(a) general superintendence and giving direction in respect of all administrative
matters of the Board;
(b) authorise any officer of the Board to scrutinise any intimation, complaint,
reference or correspondence addressed to the Board; and
(c) authorise performance of any of the functions of the Board and conduct any
of its proceedings, by an individual Member or groups of Members and to allocate
proceedings among them.
CHAPTER VI
P
OWERS, FUNCTIONS AND PROCEDURE TO BE FOLLOWED BY BOARD
27. (1) The Board shall exercise and perform the following powers and functions,
namely:—
(a) on receipt of an intimation of personal data breach under sub-section (6) of
section 8, to direct any urgent remedial or mitigation measures in the event of a
personal data breach, and to inquire into such personal data breach and impose
penalty as provided in this Act;
(b) on a complaint made by a Data Principal in respect of a personal data breach
or a breach in observance by a Data Fiduciary of its obligations in relation to her
personal data or the exercise of her rights under the provisions of this Act, or on a
reference made to it by the Central Government or a State Government, or in compliance
of the directions of any court, to inquire into such breach and impose penalty as
provided in this Act;
(c) on a complaint made by a Data Principal in respect of a breach in observance
by a Consent Manager of its obligations in relation to her personal data, to inquire
into such breach and impose penalty as provided in this Act;
(d) on receipt of an intimation of breach of any condition of registration of a
Consent Manager, to inquire into such breach and impose penalty as provided in this
Act; and
(e) on a reference made by the Central Government in respect of the breach in
observance of the provisions of sub-section  (2) of section 37 by an intermediary, to
inquire into such breach and impose penalty as provided in this Act.
(2) The Board may, for the effective discharge of its functions under the provisions of
this Act, after giving the person concerned an opportunity of being heard and after recording
reasons in writing, issue such directions as it may consider necessary to such person, who
shall be bound to comply with the same.
(3) The Board may, on a representation made to it by a person affected by a direction
issued under sub-section ( 1) or sub-section ( 2), or on a reference made by the Central
Government, modify, suspend, withdraw or cancel such direction and, while doing so,
impose such conditions as it may deem fit, subject to which the modification, suspension,
withdrawal or cancellation shall have effect.
28. (1) The Board shall function as an independent body and shall, as far as practicable,
function as a digital office, with the receipt of complaints and the allocation, hearing and
pronouncement of decisions in respect of the same being digital by design, and adopt such
techno-legal measures as may be prescribed.
(2) The Board may, on receipt of an intimation or complaint or reference or directions
as referred to in sub-section (1) of section 27, take action in accordance with the provisions
of this Act and the rules made thereunder.

controls.control_title: Establish a clear charter for the Board
controls.control: The Board shall have a clear and well-defined charter that outlines its roles, responsibilities, and objectives. This charter shall be approved by the relevant governing body and communicated to all stakeholders.

The Board shall be free from undue influence or interference from management, employees, or external parties. This includes ensuring that Board members are not subject to undue pressure or coercion in their decision-making.

The Board shall have a digital office that is equipped with the necessary technology and tools to support its operations. This includes a secure and reliable digital platform for communication, collaboration, and decision-making.

The Board shall have clearly defined roles and responsibilities for each member, including the Chairperson, Vice-Chairperson, and other members. This shall be outlined in the Board's charter and communicated to all stakeholders.
The Board shall establish a regular meeting schedule that includes both in-person and virtual meetings. This shall ensure that the Board is able to meet regularly and make timely decisions.
The Board shall provide regular training and development opportunities for its members to ensure that they have the necessary skills and knowledge to perform their roles effectively.
The Board shall maintain accurate and complete records of its meetings, decisions, and actions. This shall include minutes of meetings, resolutions, and other relevant documents.

extracted_data.requirement_title: Board to Determine Inquiry Grounds
extracted_data.article_text:
SEC. 1] THE GAZETTE OF INDIA EXTRAORDINARY 15
(3) The Board shall determine whether there are sufficient grounds to proceed with an
inquiry.
(4) In case the Board determines that there are insufficient grounds, it may, for reasons
to be recorded in writing, close the proceedings.
(5) In case the Board determines that there are sufficient grounds to proceed with
inquiry, it may, for reasons to be recorded in writing, inquire into the affairs of any person for
ascertaining whether such person is complying with or has complied with the provisions of
this Act.
(6) The Board shall conduct such inquiry following the principles of natural justice
and shall record reasons for its actions during the course of such inquiry.
(7) For the purposes of discharging its functions under this Act, the Board shall have
the same powers as are vested in a civil court under the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908, in
respect of matters relating to—
(a) summoning and enforcing the attendance of any person and examining her
on oath;
(b) receiving evidence of affidavit requiring the discovery and production of
documents;
(c) inspecting any data, book, document, register, books of account or any
other document; and
(d) such other matters as may be prescribed.
(8) The Board or its officers shall not prevent access to any premises or take into
custody any equipment or any item that may adversely affect the day-to-day functioning of
a person.
(9) The Board may require the services of any police officer or any officer of the
Central Government or a State Government to assist it for the purposes of this section and
it shall be the duty of every such officer to comply with such requisition.
(10) During the course of the inquiry, if the Board considers it necessary, it may for
reasons to be recorded in writing, issue interim orders after giving the person concerned an
opportunity of being heard.
(11) On completion of the inquiry and after giving the person concerned an opportunity
of being heard, the Board may for reasons to be recorded in writing, either close the
proceedings or proceed in accordance with section 33.
(12) At any stage after receipt of a complaint, if the Board is of the opinion that the
complaint is false or frivolous, it may issue a warning or impose costs on the complainant.

29. (1) Any person aggrieved by an order or direction made by the Board under this
Act may prefer an appeal before the Appellate Tribunal.
(2) Every appeal under sub-section (1) shall be filed within a period of sixty days from
the date of receipt of the order or direction appealed against and it shall be in such form and
manner and shall be accompanied by such fee as may be prescribed.
(3) The Appellate Tribunal may entertain an appeal after the expiry of the period
specified in sub-section (2), if it is satisfied that there was sufficient cause for not preferring
the appeal within that period.
(4) On receipt of an appeal under sub-section ( 1), the Appellate Tribunal may, after
giving the parties to the appeal, an opportunity of being heard, pass such orders thereon as
it thinks fit, confirming, modifying or setting aside the order appealed against.

controls.control: The Board shall ensure that all parties involved in the inquiry have a fair hearing and the opportunity to respond to any allegations or evidence presented, in accordance with the principles of natural justice.

The Board shall maintain confidentiality and anonymity of all parties involved in the inquiry, unless disclosure is necessary to ensure the integrity of the inquiry or to prevent harm to individuals or the organization.
The Board shall document the inquiry process, including all evidence collected, interviews conducted, and decisions made, to ensure transparency and accountability.

extracted_data.requirement: The Board shall consider whether the person realized a gain or avoided a loss as a result of the breach.
extracted_data.requirement_description: The Board must consider whether the person benefited financially or otherwise from the breach.

controls.control_title: Conduct a thorough investigation of the breach
controls.control: The Board shall conduct a thorough investigation of the breach to determine the extent of the loss or gain. This investigation should include a review of financial records, communication with affected parties, and analysis of any relevant data. The investigation should be documented and the findings presented to the Board for consideration.

controls.control_title: Identify and quantify the financial impact of the breach
controls.control: The Board shall identify and quantify the financial impact of the breach, including any realized gains or avoided losses. This should involve a detailed analysis of financial records and a review of any relevant financial statements. The financial impact should be documented and presented to the Board for consideration.

controls.control_title: Review and update policies and procedures to prevent similar breaches
controls.control: The Board shall review and update policies and procedures to prevent similar breaches from occurring in the future. This should involve a review of existing policies and procedures, identification of any gaps or weaknesses, and implementation of new or revised policies and procedures to address these gaps. The updated policies and procedures should be documented and communicated to relevant stakeholders.

controls.control_title: Consider the impact of the breach on stakeholders
controls.control: The Board shall consider the impact of the breach on stakeholders, including customers, employees, and investors. This should involve a review of any relevant data and a consideration of the potential consequences of the breach on these stakeholders. The impact on stakeholders should be documented and presented to the Board for consideration.

controls.control_title: Document the breach and its impact
controls.control: The Board shall document the breach and its impact, including any realized gains or avoided losses. This should involve a detailed record of the breach, including the date, time, and extent of the breach, as well as any relevant financial data. The documentation should be maintained in a secure and accessible location.

controls.control: Develop and provide guidance on payment plans for monetary penalties. This should include information on payment schedules, interest rates, and any applicable fees. The guidance should be clear, concise, and easily understandable by the person.

controls.control_title: Regularly Review and Update Monetary Penalty Impact Assessments
controls.control: Regularly review and update monetary penalty impact assessments to ensure they remain accurate and relevant. This should be done at least annually, or whenever there are significant changes to the person's financial circumstances.

controls.control_title: Train Staff on Monetary Penalty Impact Assessments
controls.control: Provide training to all staff involved in assessing the likely impact of monetary penalties on the person. This should include information on the assessment process, relevant factors to consider, and any applicable laws or regulations.

Maintain accurate and up-to-date records of all information exchanges with the Central Government. These records should include dates, times, and details of the information exchanged, as well as any correspondence or communication related to the information exchange.

controls.control: Implement a robust access blocking mechanism that can be triggered by intermediaries to block access to information as directed by the relevant authorities. This mechanism should be able to block access to specific URLs, IP addresses, or domains.

Establish clear and unambiguous directions for intermediaries on when and how to block access to information. These directions should be communicated in a timely manner and be easily accessible to all relevant personnel.
Conduct regular testing and validation of the access blocking mechanism to ensure it is functioning correctly and as intended. This should include testing for false positives and false negatives.

Maintain accurate and detailed records of all instances where access to information has been blocked. These records should include the date, time, and reason for blocking, as well as the specific information that was blocked.

Provide regular training and awareness programs for intermediaries on the importance of complying with directions to block access to information. This should include training on the access blocking mechanism and the procedures for reporting any issues or concerns.

extracted_data.requirement_description: This requirement ensures that civil courts do not have the authority to entertain suits or proceedings related to the Board's powers and actions.

controls.control: Include a clear disclaimer in all public documents, including the Board's website, annual reports, and other publications, stating that no civil court has jurisdiction to entertain suits or proceedings related to the Board.

Amend the Board's charter to explicitly state that no civil court has jurisdiction to entertain suits or proceedings related to the Board, and that any disputes must be resolved through arbitration or other alternative dispute resolution mechanisms.

Provide regular training and awareness programs for Board employees, including management and staff, on the jurisdictional limitations of civil courts and the procedures for resolving disputes related to the Board.

Include a statement in the Board's meeting minutes, after each meeting, confirming that no civil court has jurisdiction to entertain suits or proceedings related to the Board, and that any disputes must be resolved through arbitration or other alternative dispute resolution mechanisms.

Include provisions in all contracts and agreements entered into by the Board, stating that no civil court has jurisdiction to entertain suits or proceedings related to the Board, and that any disputes must be resolved through arbitration or other alternative dispute resolution mechanisms.

extracted_data.requirement: The Central Government may make rules to carry out the purposes of this Act.
extracted_data.requirement_description: This requirement allows the Central Government to create rules to implement the provisions of this Act, subject to certain conditions.

controls.control: Establish a committee within the Central Government to oversee the rule-making process and ensure compliance with the Act. The committee should consist of representatives from relevant departments and have the authority to review and approve rules.
Develop a clear and transparent process for making rules, including timelines, stakeholder engagement, and public consultation. The process should be documented and made available to the public.

Maintain accurate and complete records of the rule-making process, including meeting minutes, correspondence, and decisions. These records should be retained for a minimum of 5 years and made available to the public upon request.

Conduct public consultation and engagement on proposed rules, including publishing draft rules, soliciting feedback, and responding to comments. This should be done in a transparent and timely manner to ensure that the public has an opportunity to participate in the rule-making process.

Regularly review and update rules to ensure they remain relevant, effective, and compliant with the Act. This should be done at least every 2 years, or as needed, to reflect changes in the Act or other relevant laws and regulations.

controls.control: Regularly review and update data processing rules to ensure they remain relevant and compliant with changing regulations and business needs.
Maintain accurate and up-to-date documentation of all data processing rules, including the purpose, scope, and procedures for implementing and enforcing them.
Establish procedures for responding to data subject requests for access, correction, deletion, and restriction of processing, in accordance with applicable laws and regulations.
Provide regular training to employees on data processing rules, including their roles and responsibilities in implementing and enforcing them.
Establish a formal approval process for new or amended data processing rules, involving relevant stakeholders and ensuring that all rules are compliant with applicable laws and regulations.
Regularly monitor and audit data processing activities to ensure compliance with established rules and regulations, and take corrective action as necessary.

controls.control: Establish clear and concise notice requirements for Data Principals, including the manner of notice, to ensure transparency and accountability.

Ensure that notices to Data Principals are translated into languages that are easily understood by the relevant population, to avoid language barriers and promote inclusivity.

controls.control_title: Establish a Process for Reporting Non-Compliance

controls.control_title: Provide Training on Accountability and Obligations

Conduct regular audits and reviews to ensure that the Consent Manager is meeting the defined accountability and obligations, and to identify areas for improvement.

controls.control_title: Implement a clear registration process for Consent Manager
controls.control: Establish a well-documented and easily accessible registration process for Consent Manager, including clear instructions and required information. This process should be easily discoverable by users and should not require excessive technical expertise.

Implement input validation during the registration process to ensure that all required fields are populated with valid data. This includes checking for missing or invalid information, such as email addresses or passwords.
Offer clear instructions and support for users who are experiencing difficulties with the registration process. This can include FAQs, user guides, or contact information for technical support.

controls.control_title: Implement secure storage of user registration data
controls.control: Store user registration data securely, using encryption and access controls to prevent unauthorized access or data breaches. This includes storing sensitive information, such as passwords or personal data.
Monitor and log all registration activity, including successful and failed registrations, to help identify potential security issues or areas for improvement.

controls.control_title: Provide a clear and concise registration agreement
controls.control: Provide a clear and concise registration agreement that outlines the terms and conditions of using the Consent Manager, including any applicable laws or regulations.

extracted_data.requirement: Rules may specify the form and manner of intimation of personal data breach.
extracted_data.requirement_description: This requirement allows the Central Government to create rules that specify how personal data breaches must be reported to the Board, as required by section 8.

controls.control_title: Establish a Personal Data Breach Notification Policy
controls.control: Develop and implement a clear policy that outlines the form and manner of intimation of personal data breaches. The policy should include procedures for identifying, assessing, and notifying affected individuals and regulatory bodies.

controls.control_title: Designate a Data Breach Notification Officer
controls.control: Appoint a dedicated officer responsible for managing personal data breaches, including coordinating notifications and communicating with affected individuals and regulatory bodies.

controls.control_title: Develop a Personal Data Breach Notification Template
controls.control: Create a standardized template for notifying affected individuals and regulatory bodies in the event of a personal data breach. The template should include essential information such as the nature of the breach, affected data, and steps taken to mitigate the breach.

controls.control_title: Conduct Regular Training on Personal Data Breach Notification Procedures
controls.control: Provide regular training to employees on the procedures for identifying, assessing, and notifying personal data breaches. This includes training on the use of the personal data breach notification template and the role of the designated data breach notification officer.

controls.control_title: Establish a Personal Data Breach Notification Communication Plan
controls.control: Develop a plan for communicating with affected individuals and regulatory bodies in the event of a personal data breach. This includes identifying the most effective communication channels and protocols for notification.

controls.control_title: Implement a Personal Data Breach Notification System
controls.control: Develop and implement a system for tracking and managing personal data breaches, including a notification system for affected individuals and regulatory bodies. The system should be able to generate notifications, track responses, and provide reporting capabilities.

controls.control_title: Publish Business Contact Information of Data Protection Officer on Public Website
controls.control: The business contact information of the Data Protection Officer (DPO) must be published on the organization's public website, making it easily accessible to data subjects and other stakeholders.

controls.control_title: Verify Accuracy and Completeness of Published Contact Information
controls.control: The organization must regularly verify the accuracy and completeness of the published contact information of the DPO, ensuring that it is up-to-date and reflects the current contact details.

controls.control_title: Provide Alternative Contact Methods for Data Subjects
controls.control: In addition to publishing the DPO's contact information on the public website, the organization must also provide alternative contact methods for data subjects, such as email or phone numbers, to facilitate communication and reporting of concerns.

controls.control_title: Train Staff on Contact Information Procedures
controls.control: All staff members must be trained on the procedures for accessing and using the DPO's contact information, ensuring that they can effectively communicate with data subjects and respond to their concerns.

controls.control: Implement an explicit consent mechanism that clearly communicates the purpose of data collection and processing to users. This can be achieved through a pop-up or banner on the website or application that requires users to actively opt-in to data collection.
Use clear and concise language in consent requests to ensure users understand what they are consenting to. Avoid using technical jargon or complex language that may confuse users.
Record users' consent decisions, including the date and time of consent, to provide a clear audit trail and demonstrate compliance with consent requirements.
Make consent information easily accessible to users, including information about data collection and processing, through a clear and prominent link on the website or application.

Provide an opt-out mechanism that allows users to withdraw their consent at any time. This can be achieved through a link or button on the website or application that allows users to opt-out of data collection.

controls.control: Establish a clear and concise definition of the classes of Data Fiduciaries, including but not limited to, individuals, organizations, and government agencies, to ensure transparency and accountability in data processing.

controls.control_title: Specify Purposes of Processing Personal Data of a Child
controls.control: Clearly define the purposes for which personal data of a child will be processed, including but not limited to, obtaining consent, providing services, and marketing, to ensure that the processing is lawful and necessary.

controls.control_title: Obtain Parental Consent for Processing Personal Data of a Child
controls.control: Implement a process to obtain verifiable parental consent before processing personal data of a child, including but not limited to, providing clear information about the processing purposes and obtaining explicit consent from the parent or guardian.

Offer an opt-out mechanism for children to prevent their personal data from being processed for marketing or other purposes, ensuring that they have control over their data and can exercise their rights.

controls.control_title: Document Data Fiduciary Classes and Processing Purposes
controls.control: Maintain accurate and up-to-date records of the classes of Data Fiduciaries and the purposes for which personal data of a child is processed, to ensure transparency and accountability in data processing.

controls.control_title: Train Staff on Data Fiduciary Classes and Processing Purposes
controls.control: Provide regular training to staff on the classes of Data Fiduciaries and the purposes for which personal data of a child is processed, to ensure that they understand their roles and responsibilities in data processing.

controls.control: Establish a clear scope and objectives for the Data Protection Impact Assessment (DPIA) process. This includes identifying the type of data involved, the processing activities, and the potential risks to individuals.
Identify and engage with relevant stakeholders, including data protection officers, business leaders, and technical experts, to ensure that all perspectives are considered during the DPIA process.

controls.control_title: Conduct a Data Protection Risk Assessment
controls.control: Conduct a thorough risk assessment to identify potential data protection risks associated with the processing activities. This includes assessing the likelihood and impact of each risk.
Maintain a comprehensive record of the DPIA process, including the scope, objectives, stakeholders, risks, and mitigation measures. This documentation should be accessible to relevant stakeholders.
Regularly review and update DPIA documents to ensure they remain accurate and relevant. This includes updating the scope, objectives, and mitigation measures as necessary.
Ensure that the data protection officer is involved in the DPIA process and provides guidance on data protection compliance. This includes reviewing and approving DPIA documents.

controls.control_title: Define Clear Requirements for Other Measures
controls.control: The Significant Data Fiduciary shall define clear requirements for other measures that the rules specify, including but not limited to, data retention, data archiving, and data destruction. These requirements shall be documented and communicated to all relevant stakeholders.

controls.control_title: Establish a Process for Review and Approval of Other Measures
controls.control: The Significant Data Fiduciary shall establish a process for reviewing and approving other measures that the rules specify. This process shall ensure that all other measures are compliant with the rules and relevant laws and regulations.

The Significant Data Fiduciary shall document all other measures that the rules specify, including but not limited to, data retention, data archiving, and data destruction. These documents shall be maintained and updated as necessary.

The Significant Data Fiduciary shall train all personnel on the other measures that the rules specify, including but not limited to, data retention, data archiving, and data destruction. This training shall be provided on an ongoing basis and shall ensure that all personnel understand their roles and responsibilities in implementing these measures.

controls.control_title: Monitor and Report on Other Measures
controls.control: The Significant Data Fiduciary shall monitor and report on the implementation of other measures that the rules specify. This shall include regular reviews and assessments to ensure that all other measures are compliant with the rules and relevant laws and regulations.

controls.control: Establish clear and concise guidelines for Data Principals to make requests to the Data Fiduciary, including the required information and format for the request.
Implement a tracking system to monitor and respond to requests from Data Principals in a timely and efficient manner, ensuring that all requests are acknowledged and addressed.
Develop a standardized request form or template that Data Principals must use when making a request to the Data Fiduciary, ensuring that all necessary information is provided.

Send an acknowledgement and notification to Data Principals when their request is received, processed, and completed, ensuring that they are informed of the status of their request.
Maintain a record of all requests from Data Principals, including the request details, response, and outcome, to ensure transparency and accountability.

extracted_data.requirement: Rules may specify the manner in which a Data Principal shall make a request to the Data Fiduciary for erasure of personal data.
extracted_data.requirement_description: This requirement allows the Central Government to create rules that specify how Data Principals must make requests to Data Fiduciaries to erase personal data, as required by section 12.

controls.control: The Data Fiduciary shall provide clear and conspicuous notice to the Data Principal of the manner in which they can request erasure of personal data, including any specific requirements or procedures that must be followed.

The Data Fiduciary shall provide a request form or process that allows the Data Principal to easily and efficiently submit a request for erasure of personal data, including any necessary documentation or information.

The Data Fiduciary shall track and acknowledge all requests for erasure of personal data, including providing the Data Principal with a confirmation of receipt and an estimated timeframe for completion.

The Data Fiduciary shall ensure that the request form or process for erasure of personal data is accessible to all Data Principals, including those with disabilities, and is available in multiple languages if necessary.

The Data Fiduciary shall establish a clear and documented procedure for erasure of personal data, including the steps to be taken to identify and delete or anonymize the data, and the measures to be taken to prevent unauthorized access or disclosure.
The Data Fiduciary shall notify the Data Principal once the erasure of personal data has been completed, and provide confirmation that the data has been deleted or anonymized.

extracted_data.requirement: Rules may specify the period within which the Data Fiduciary shall respond to any grievances.
extracted_data.requirement_description: This requirement allows the Central Government to create rules that specify how long Data Fiduciaries must respond to grievances, as required by section 13.

controls.control: Establish a clear and measurable timeframe for responding to grievances, including the maximum number of days or hours within which the Data Fiduciary shall respond. This timeframe should be communicated to all stakeholders, including customers and employees.

Develop a documented process for responding to grievances, including the steps to be taken, the personnel responsible, and the escalation procedures in case of unresolved grievances. This process should be communicated to all stakeholders and made available on the Data Fiduciary's website or other publicly accessible location.

controls.control_title: Monitor and Report Grievance Response Times
controls.control: Regularly monitor and track the response times for grievances, including the average time taken to respond and the number of grievances resolved within the specified timeframe. This information should be reported to management and used to identify areas for improvement.

Provide regular training to personnel on the grievance response process, including the importance of timely responses, the procedures for escalating unresolved grievances, and the communication protocols for interacting with customers and other stakeholders.

controls.control_title: Communicate Grievance Response Timeframe to Stakeholders
controls.control: Communicate the grievance response timeframe to all stakeholders, including customers, employees, and partners, through various channels such as the website, social media, and customer service interactions.

extracted_data.requirement: Rules and notifications shall be laid before each House of Parliament within thirty days.
extracted_data.requirement_description: Organizations must submit rules and notifications to Parliament within thirty days for review and approval.

controls.control: Establish a committee responsible for reviewing and approving rules and notifications before they are laid before each House of Parliament. The committee should comprise representatives from relevant departments and stakeholders to ensure that rules and notifications are thoroughly reviewed and meet the required standards.

Develop a clear and documented process for reviewing rules and notifications, including timelines, checklists, and approval mechanisms. This process should be communicated to all relevant stakeholders and departments to ensure consistency and adherence to the process.

Implement a system to track the status of rules and notifications, including the date they are submitted, reviewed, and laid before each House of Parliament. This system should provide real-time updates and alerts to relevant stakeholders to ensure timely compliance with the 30-day deadline.

Conduct regular audits to ensure that rules and notifications are being laid before each House of Parliament within the 30-day deadline. These audits should identify areas for improvement and provide recommendations for enhancing compliance with the requirement.

Designate a compliance officer responsible for ensuring that rules and notifications are laid before each House of Parliament within the 30-day deadline. The compliance officer should be accountable for implementing and monitoring the rule review process and notification tracking system.

extracted_data.requirement: The Central Government shall not increase penalties in the Schedule by more than twice the original amount.
extracted_data.requirement_description: The Central Government is prohibited from increasing penalties in the Schedule by more than twice the original amount.

controls.control: Implement a system to track and enforce the penalty increase threshold, ensuring that penalties are not increased by more than twice the original amount. This system should be integrated with the penalty calculation module and provide real-time alerts and notifications when the threshold is exceeded.

Regularly review and update the penalty calculation module to ensure that it accurately reflects the penalty increase threshold. This review should be performed at least quarterly and include testing of the module with various scenarios to ensure its accuracy and reliability.

Maintain up-to-date documentation of the penalty increase threshold, including the calculation methodology and any relevant exceptions or exemptions. This documentation should be easily accessible to all relevant stakeholders and updated whenever changes are made to the threshold or calculation methodology.

Implement automated controls to prevent penalties from being increased by more than twice the original amount. This can be achieved through the use of business rules, triggers, or other automated mechanisms that prevent excessive penalty increases.

Provide regular training to staff on the penalty increase threshold and the procedures for enforcing it. This training should include scenarios and examples to help staff understand the threshold and how to apply it in practice.

extracted_data.requirement: The Central Government shall not make orders that are inconsistent with the Act.
extracted_data.requirement_description: The Central Government is required to make orders that are consistent with the Act and necessary to remove difficulties.

controls.control: Develop and maintain clear guidelines and procedures for making orders that are consistent with the Act. These guidelines should be easily accessible to all relevant personnel and should include a clear explanation of the Act and its requirements.

Designate a central authority responsible for ensuring that all orders made by the Central Government are consistent with the Act. This authority should be empowered to review and approve all orders before they are issued.

Conduct regular reviews and audits to ensure that all orders made by the Central Government are consistent with the Act. These reviews should be conducted at least annually and should include a thorough examination of all orders made during the review period.
Provide regular training and awareness programs for all personnel involved in making orders to ensure that they understand the requirements of the Act and the importance of consistency with the Act.
Maintain a complete and accurate record of all orders made by the Central Government, including a clear explanation of the basis for each order and any relevant supporting documentation.

Establish a clear and transparent procedure for handling complaints about orders made by the Central Government that are alleged to be inconsistent with the Act. This procedure should include a clear explanation of the process for submitting complaints and the timeframe for resolving complaints.

extracted_data.requirement: Orders made under section 43 shall be laid before each House of Parliament.
extracted_data.requirement_description: Organizations must submit orders made under section 43 to Parliament for review and approval.

controls.control_title: Establish a Clear Procedure for Laying Orders
controls.control: Develop and document a clear procedure for laying orders made under section 43 before each House of Parliament. This procedure should include timelines, responsible personnel, and communication protocols to ensure transparency and accountability.

controls.control_title: Designate a Responsible Officer for Laying Orders
controls.control: Appoint a responsible officer to oversee the laying of orders made under section 43. This officer should be accountable for ensuring that all orders are properly documented, reviewed, and presented to Parliament within the required timeframe.

controls.control_title: Maintain a Record of Laid Orders
controls.control: Keep a comprehensive record of all orders made under section 43, including the date of laying, the House of Parliament where laid, and any relevant documentation or supporting materials. This record should be easily accessible and maintained for a minimum of 5 years.

controls.control_title: Ensure Transparency and Accessibility of Laid Orders
controls.control: Make all orders made under section 43 publicly available on the organization's website or through a designated portal. This should include providing clear summaries, explanations, and supporting documentation to facilitate understanding and scrutiny by Parliament and the public.

controls.control_title: Establish a Review Process for Laid Orders
controls.control: Develop a review process to assess the effectiveness and impact of orders made under section 43. This process should involve regular evaluation, feedback mechanisms, and adjustments to ensure that the orders align with the organization's goals and objectives.
